mn3:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn3:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn3:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn3:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, be my heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh.
mn3:2.1.comm: “Things of the flesh” renders āmisa, literally “meat”. In Vedic sacrifice the flesh of the slaughtered beast was made holy and fit for the gods (Rig Veda 1.162.10). In this way the guilt of killing was assuaged and the flesh became allowable for the brahmin priests. Here the “flesh” is extended by implication to the material pleasures of the world.

mn3:2.2.eng: Out of sympathy for you, I think,

mn3:2.3.pli: ‘kinti me sāvakā dhammadāyādā bhaveyyuṃ, no āmisadāyādā’ti.
mn3:2.3.eng: ‘How can my disciples become heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh?’

mn3:2.4.pli: Tumhe ca me, bhikkhave, āmisadāyādā bhaveyyātha no dhammadāyādā, tumhepi tena ādiyā bhaveyyātha:
mn3:2.4.eng: If you become heirs in things of the flesh, not in the teaching, that will make you liable to the accusation:
mn3:2.4.comm: Text’s ādiya (and variant ādissā) are future passive participles from √dis (“point”) having the sense “liable to be pointed out or accused”.

mn3:2.5.eng: ‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs in things of the flesh, not in the teaching.’

mn3:2.6.eng: And it will make me liable to the accusation:

mn3:2.7.eng: ‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs in things of the flesh, not in the teaching.’

mn3:2.8.pli: Tumhe ca me, bhikkhave, dhammadāyādā bhaveyyātha, no āmisadāyādā, tumhepi tena na ādiyā bhaveyyātha:
mn3:2.8.eng: If you become heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh, that will make you not liable to the accusation:

mn3:2.9.eng: ‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh.’

mn3:2.10.eng: And it will make me not liable to the accusation:

mn3:2.11.eng: ‘The Teacher’s disciples live as heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh.’

mn3:2.12.pli: Tasmātiha me, bhikkhave, dhammadāyādā bhavatha, mā āmisadāyādā.
mn3:2.12.eng: So, mendicants, be my heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh.

mn3:2.13.eng: Out of sympathy for you, I think,

mn3:2.14.pli: ‘kinti me sāvakā dhammadāyādā bhaveyyuṃ, no āmisadāyādā’ti.
mn3:2.14.eng: ‘How can my disciples become heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh?’

mn3:3.1.pli: Idhāhaṃ, bhikkhave, bhuttāvī assaṃ pavārito paripuṇṇo pariyosito suhito yāvadattho;
mn3:3.1.eng: Suppose that I had eaten and refused more food, being full, and having had as much as I needed.
mn3:3.1.comm: A mendicant tries to eat just what they need. In some circumstances, especially when eating on invitation in a house, the donors will first place a modest amount of food in the bowl, then offer more during the meal if it is needed. This passage concerns such extra food that has been refused.

mn3:3.2.pli: siyā ca me piṇḍapāto atirekadhammo chaḍḍanīyadhammo.
mn3:3.2.eng: And there was some extra almsfood that was going to be thrown away.

mn3:3.3.eng: Then two mendicants were to come who were weak with hunger.

mn3:3.5.pli: ‘ahaṃ khomhi, bhikkhave, bhuttāvī pavārito paripuṇṇo pariyosito suhito yāvadattho;
mn3:3.5.eng: ‘Mendicants, I have eaten and refused more food, being full, and having had as much as I need.

mn3:3.6.pli: atthi ca me ayaṃ piṇḍapāto atirekadhammo chaḍḍanīyadhammo.
mn3:3.6.eng: And there is this extra almsfood that’s going to be thrown away.

mn3:3.7.pli: Sace ākaṅkhatha, bhuñjatha, no ce tumhe bhuñjissatha, idānāhaṃ appaharite vā chaḍḍessāmi, appāṇake vā udake opilāpessāmī’ti.
mn3:3.7.eng: Eat it if you like. Otherwise I’ll throw it out where there is little that grows, or drop it into water that has no living creatures.’

mn3:3.8.eng: Then one of those mendicants thought,

mn3:3.9.pli: ‘bhagavā kho bhuttāvī pavārito paripuṇṇo pariyosito suhito yāvadattho;
mn3:3.9.eng: ‘The Buddha has eaten and refused more food.

mn3:3.10.pli: atthi cāyaṃ bhagavato piṇḍapāto atirekadhammo chaḍḍanīyadhammo.
mn3:3.10.eng: And he has some extra almsfood that’s going to be thrown away.

mn3:3.11.pli: Sace mayaṃ na bhuñjissāma, idāni bhagavā appaharite vā chaḍḍessati, appāṇake vā udake opilāpessati.
mn3:3.11.eng: If we don’t eat it he’ll throw it away.

mn3:3.12.eng: But the Buddha has also said:

mn3:3.13.eng: “Be my heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh.”

mn3:3.14.eng: And almsfood is one of the things of the flesh.

mn3:3.15.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ imaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ abhuñjitvā imināva jighacchādubbalyena evaṃ imaṃ rattindivaṃ vītināmeyyan’ti.
mn3:3.15.eng: Instead of eating this almsfood, why don’t I spend this day and night weak with hunger?’

mn3:3.16.pli: So taṃ piṇḍapātaṃ abhuñjitvā teneva jighacchādubbalyena evaṃ taṃ rattindivaṃ vītināmeyya.

mn3:3.17.eng: Then the second of those mendicants thought,

mn3:3.18.pli: ‘bhagavā kho bhuttāvī pavārito paripuṇṇo pariyosito suhito yāvadattho;
mn3:3.18.eng: ‘The Buddha has eaten and refused more food.

mn3:3.19.pli: atthi cāyaṃ bhagavato piṇḍapāto atirekadhammo chaḍḍanīyadhammo.
mn3:3.19.eng: And he has some extra almsfood that’s going to be thrown away.

mn3:3.20.pli: Sace mayaṃ na bhuñjissāma, idāni bhagavā appaharite vā chaḍḍessati, appāṇake vā udake opilāpessati.
mn3:3.20.eng: If we don’t eat it he’ll throw it away.

mn3:3.21.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ imaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ bhuñjitvā jighacchādubbalyaṃ paṭivinodetvā evaṃ imaṃ rattindivaṃ vītināmeyyan’ti.
mn3:3.21.eng: Why don’t I eat this almsfood, then spend the day and night having got rid of my hunger and weakness?’

mn3:3.22.pli: So taṃ piṇḍapātaṃ bhuñjitvā jighacchādubbalyaṃ paṭivinodetvā evaṃ taṃ rattindivaṃ vītināmeyya.

mn3:3.23.pli: Kiñcāpi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu taṃ piṇḍapātaṃ bhuñjitvā jighacchādubbalyaṃ paṭivinodetvā evaṃ taṃ rattindivaṃ vītināmeyya, atha kho asuyeva me purimo bhikkhu pujjataro ca pāsaṃsataro ca.
mn3:3.23.eng: Even though that mendicant, after eating the almsfood, spent the day and night rid of hunger and weakness, it is the former mendicant who is more worthy of respect and praise.

mn3:3.25.pli: Tañhi tassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno dīgharattaṃ appicchatāya santuṭṭhiyā sallekhāya subharatāya vīriyārambhāya saṃvattissati.
mn3:3.25.eng: Because for a long time that will conduce to that mendicant being of few wishes, content, self-effacing, unburdensome, and energetic.
mn3:3.25.comm: This is an example of the “defilements given up by using” (MN 2:14.2). It makes a point: short term discomfort is outweighed by the benefits of overcoming greed. Note that the Buddha encouraged mendicants to eat regularly, and did not support fasting or other extreme diets.

mn3:3.26.pli: Tasmātiha me, bhikkhave, dhammadāyādā bhavatha, mā āmisadāyādā.
mn3:3.26.eng: So, mendicants, be my heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh.

mn3:3.27.eng: Out of sympathy for you, I think,

mn3:3.28.pli: ‘kinti me sāvakā dhammadāyādā bhaveyyuṃ, no āmisadāyādā’”ti.
mn3:3.28.eng: ‘How can my disciples become heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh?’”

mn3:4.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn3:4.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato uṭṭhāyāsanā vihāraṃ pāvisi.
mn3:4.2.eng: When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.

mn3:4.3.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto acirapakkantassa bhagavato bhikkhū āmantesi:
mn3:4.3.eng: Then soon after the Buddha left, Venerable Sāriputta said to the mendicants,
mn3:4.3.comm: This marks the first time in the Majjhimanikāya that we hear a teaching from a disciple. Sāriputta was the Buddha’s leading disciple, famed for his wisdom. He gave many teachings in the suttas, typically, as here, preferring systematic expositions.

mn3:4.5.pli: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosuṃ.

mn3:5.1.pli: “Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, satthu pavivittassa viharato sāvakā vivekaṃ nānusikkhanti, kittāvatā ca pana satthu pavivittassa viharato sāvakā vivekamanusikkhantī”ti?
mn3:5.1.eng: “Reverends, how do the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion not train in seclusion? And how do they train in seclusion?”
mn3:5.1.comm: Sāriputta continues on a similar theme, phrased in terms of “seclusion” (viveka) rather than “things of the flesh” (āmisa). Seclusion is explained in the commentaries as threefold: physical seclusion achieved by living a virtuous life in a quiet place; mental seclusion from the hindrances achieved through the jhānas; and seclusion from attachments, namely Nibbāna.

mn3:5.2.pli: “Dūratopi kho mayaṃ, āvuso, āgacchāma āyasmato sāriputtassa santike etassa bhāsitassa atthamaññātuṃ.
mn3:5.2.eng: “Reverend, we would travel a long way to learn the meaning of this statement in the presence of Venerable Sāriputta.

mn3:5.3.pli: Sādhu vatāyasmantaṃyeva sāriputtaṃ paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho;
mn3:5.3.eng: May Venerable Sāriputta himself please clarify the meaning of this.

mn3:5.4.eng: The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

mn3:5.5.pli: “Tena hāvuso, suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn3:5.5.eng: “Well then, reverends, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn3:5.6.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosuṃ.

mn3:6.1.pli: “Kittāvatā nu kho, āvuso, satthu pavivittassa viharato sāvakā vivekaṃ nānusikkhanti?
mn3:6.1.eng: “Reverends, how do the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion not train in seclusion?

mn3:6.2.pli: Idhāvuso, satthu pavivittassa viharato sāvakā vivekaṃ nānusikkhanti,
mn3:6.2.eng: The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion do not train in seclusion.

mn3:6.3.pli: yesañca dhammānaṃ satthā pahānamāha, te ca dhamme nappajahanti,
mn3:6.3.eng: They don’t give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.

mn3:6.4.pli: bāhulikā ca honti, sāthalikā, okkamane pubbaṅgamā, paviveke nikkhittadhurā.
mn3:6.4.eng: They’re indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion.

mn3:6.5.pli: Tatrāvuso, therā bhikkhū tīhi ṭhānehi gārayhā bhavanti.
mn3:6.5.eng: In this case, the senior mendicants should be criticized on three grounds.
mn3:6.5.comm: “Senior mendicants” (therā bhikkhū) have been ordained for more than ten rains retreats, i.e. ten years.

mn3:6.6.eng: ‘The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion do not train in seclusion.’

mn3:6.7.pli: iminā paṭhamena ṭhānena therā bhikkhū gārayhā bhavanti.

mn3:6.8.pli: ‘Yesañca dhammānaṃ satthā pahānamāha te ca dhamme nappajahantī’ti—
mn3:6.8.eng: ‘They don’t give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.’

mn3:6.9.pli: iminā dutiyena ṭhānena therā bhikkhū gārayhā bhavanti.

mn3:6.10.pli: ‘Bāhulikā ca, sāthalikā, okkamane pubbaṅgamā, paviveke nikkhittadhurā’ti—
mn3:6.10.eng: ‘They’re indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion.’

mn3:6.11.pli: iminā tatiyena ṭhānena therā bhikkhū gārayhā bhavanti.

mn3:6.12.pli: Therā, āvuso, bhikkhū imehi tīhi ṭhānehi gārayhā bhavanti.
mn3:6.12.eng: The senior mendicants should be criticized on these three grounds.

mn3:6.13.eng: In this case, the middle mendicants
mn3:6.13.comm: “Middle mendicants” (majjhimā bhikkhū) have between five and ten rains.

mn3:6.14.pli: navā bhikkhū tīhi ṭhānehi gārayhā bhavanti.
mn3:6.14.eng: and the junior mendicants should be criticized on the same three grounds.
mn3:6.14.comm: “Junior mendicants” (navā bhikkhū) have less than five rains.

mn3:6.16.pli: iminā paṭhamena ṭhānena navā bhikkhū gārayhā bhavanti.

mn3:6.17.pli: ‘Yesañca dhammānaṃ satthā pahānamāha te ca dhamme nappajahantī’ti—

mn3:6.18.pli: iminā dutiyena ṭhānena navā bhikkhū gārayhā bhavanti.

mn3:6.19.pli: ‘Bāhulikā ca honti, sāthalikā, okkamane pubbaṅgamā, paviveke nikkhittadhurā’ti—

mn3:6.20.pli: iminā tatiyena ṭhānena navā bhikkhū gārayhā bhavanti.

mn3:6.21.pli: Navā, āvuso, bhikkhū imehi tīhi ṭhānehi gārayhā bhavanti.

mn3:6.22.pli: Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, satthu pavivittassa viharato sāvakā vivekaṃ nānusikkhanti.
mn3:6.22.eng: This is how the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion do not train in seclusion.

mn3:7.1.pli: Kittāvatā ca panāvuso, satthu pavivittassa viharato sāvakā vivekamanusikkhanti?
mn3:7.1.eng: And how do the disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion?

mn3:7.2.pli: Idhāvuso, satthu pavivittassa viharato sāvakā vivekamanusikkhanti—
mn3:7.2.eng: The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion.

mn3:7.3.pli: yesañca dhammānaṃ satthā pahānamāha te ca dhamme pajahanti;
mn3:7.3.eng: They give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.

mn3:7.4.pli: na ca bāhulikā honti, na sāthalikā okkamane nikkhittadhurā paviveke pubbaṅgamā.
mn3:7.4.eng: They’re not indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion.

mn3:7.5.pli: Tatrāvuso, therā bhikkhū tīhi ṭhānehi pāsaṃsā bhavanti.
mn3:7.5.eng: In this case, the senior mendicants should be praised on three grounds.

mn3:7.6.eng: ‘The disciples of a teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion.’

mn3:7.7.pli: iminā paṭhamena ṭhānena therā bhikkhū pāsaṃsā bhavanti.

mn3:7.8.pli: ‘Yesañca dhammānaṃ satthā pahānamāha te ca dhamme pajahantī’ti—
mn3:7.8.eng: ‘They give up what the Teacher tells them to give up.’

mn3:7.9.pli: iminā dutiyena ṭhānena therā bhikkhū pāsaṃsā bhavanti.

mn3:7.10.pli: ‘Na ca bāhulikā, na sāthalikā okkamane nikkhittadhurā paviveke pubbaṅgamā’ti—
mn3:7.10.eng: ‘They’re not indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion.’

mn3:7.11.pli: iminā tatiyena ṭhānena therā bhikkhū pāsaṃsā bhavanti.

mn3:7.12.pli: Therā, āvuso, bhikkhū imehi tīhi ṭhānehi pāsaṃsā bhavanti.
mn3:7.12.eng: The senior mendicants should be praised on these three grounds.

mn3:7.13.eng: In this case, the middle mendicants

mn3:7.14.pli: navā bhikkhū tīhi ṭhānehi pāsaṃsā bhavanti.
mn3:7.14.eng: and the junior mendicants should be praised on the same three grounds.

mn3:7.16.pli: iminā paṭhamena ṭhānena navā bhikkhū pāsaṃsā bhavanti.

mn3:7.17.pli: ‘Yesañca dhammānaṃ satthā pahānamāha te ca dhamme pajahantī’ti—

mn3:7.18.pli: iminā dutiyena ṭhānena navā bhikkhū pāsaṃsā bhavanti.

mn3:7.19.pli: ‘Na ca bāhulikā, na sāthalikā okkamane nikkhittadhurā paviveke pubbaṅgamā’ti—

mn3:7.20.pli: iminā tatiyena ṭhānena navā bhikkhū pāsaṃsā bhavanti.

mn3:7.21.pli: Navā, āvuso, bhikkhū imehi tīhi ṭhānehi pāsaṃsā bhavanti.

mn3:7.22.pli: Ettāvatā kho, āvuso, satthu pavivittassa viharato sāvakā vivekamanusikkhanti.
mn3:7.22.eng: This is how the disciples of a Teacher who lives in seclusion train in seclusion.

mn3:8.1.pli: Tatrāvuso, lobho ca pāpako doso ca pāpako.
mn3:8.1.eng: The bad thing here is greed and hate.

mn3:8.2.pli: Lobhassa ca pahānāya dosassa ca pahānāya atthi majjhimā paṭipadā cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati.
mn3:8.2.eng: There is a middle way of practice for giving up greed and hate. It gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.
mn3:8.2.comm: Sāriputta is adapting a passage from the Buddha’s first sermon, the Dhammacakkappavattanasutta (SN 56.11:2.4).

mn3:8.3.pli: Katamā ca sā, āvuso, majjhimā paṭipadā cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati?
mn3:8.3.eng: And what is that middle way of practice?

mn3:8.4.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
mn3:8.4.comm: The noble eightfold path is the fourth of the four noble truths. It is defined in detail at MN 141:23.2.

mn3:8.5.pli: sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappo sammāvācā sammākammanto sammāājīvo sammāvāyāmo sammāsati sammāsamādhi.
mn3:8.5.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

mn3:8.6.pli: Ayaṃ kho sā, āvuso, majjhimā paṭipadā cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati.
mn3:8.6.eng: This is that middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.

mn3:9-15.1.pli: Tatrāvuso, kodho ca pāpako upanāho ca pāpako …pe…
mn3:9-15.1.eng: The bad thing here is anger and acrimony. …

mn3:9-15.2.pli: makkho ca pāpako paḷāso ca pāpako,

mn3:9-15.5.pli: thambho ca pāpako sārambho ca pāpako,

mn3:9-15.6.pli: māno ca pāpako atimāno ca pāpako,

mn3:9-15.7.pli: mado ca pāpako pamādo ca pāpako.

mn3:9-15.8.pli: Madassa ca pahānāya pamādassa ca pahānāya atthi majjhimā paṭipadā cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati.
mn3:9-15.8.eng: There is a middle way of practice for giving up vanity and negligence. It gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.

mn3:9-15.9.pli: Katamā ca sā, āvuso, majjhimā paṭipadā cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati?
mn3:9-15.9.eng: And what is that middle way of practice?

mn3:9-15.10.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

mn3:9-15.11.pli: sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappo sammāvācā sammākammanto sammāājīvo sammāvāyāmo sammāsati sammāsamādhi.
mn3:9-15.11.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

mn3:9-15.12.pli: Ayaṃ kho sā, āvuso, majjhimā paṭipadā cakkhukaraṇī ñāṇakaraṇī upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattatī”ti.
mn3:9-15.12.eng: This is that middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.”

mn3:9-15.13.eng: This is what Venerable Sāriputta said.

mn3:9-15.14.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn3:9-15.14.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what Sāriputta said.
